elements.content: The development of selective sensing materials for amine detection has received considerable attentions because amines have high toxicity and exist widely. In this article, we demonstrate for the first time that a degree of discriminative detection of alkylamines can be achieved by a metal–organic coordination material. The material is derived from CdII and 4,4′-bipyridinium-1,1′-bis­(phenylene-3-carboxylate), shows 1D channels lined with electron-deficient viologen chromophores, and exhibits different colors upon contact with amine vapors of different molecular sizes and types (primary, secondary, and tertiary). The vapochromism is attributable to electron transfer from the amine group to viologen. The discrimination between amines is because the analyte–receptor interactions, which either directly mediate or indirectly affect electron transfer, are influenced by the number of the N–H bonds in the amine molecule, the size of the amine molecule relative to the receptor channel and the steric hindrance for the electron donor–acceptor contacts. The material also shows reversible photo- and hydrochromism owing to stimuli-induced reversible electron transfer. The compound can be deposited in paper simply by spraying the mixture solution of the starting metal salt and the ligand. The paper can be used as portable test strips for visual and differentiable detection of amines and as erasable inkless printing medium.
elements.clean_text: The development of selective sensing materials for amine detection has received considerable attentions because amines have high toxicity and exist widely. In this article, we demonstrate for the first time that a degree of discriminative detection of alkylamines can be achieved by a metal-organic coordination material. The material is derived from CdII and 4,4'-bipyridinium-1,1'-bis(phenylene-3-carboxylate), shows 1D channels lined with electron-deficient viologen chromophores, and exhibits different colors upon contact with amine vapors of different molecular sizes and types (primary, secondary, and tertiary). The vapochromism is attributable to electron transfer from the amine group to viologen. The discrimination between amines is because the analyte-receptor interactions, which either directly mediate or indirectly affect electron transfer, are influenced by the number of the N-H bonds in the amine molecule, the size of the amine molecule relative to the receptor channel and the steric hindrance for the electron donor-acceptor contacts. The material also shows reversible photo- and hydrochromism owing to stimuli-induced reversible electron transfer. The compound can be deposited in paper simply by spraying the mixture solution of the starting metal salt and the ligand. The paper can be used as portable test strips for visual and differentiable detection of amines and as erasable inkless printing medium.

elements.content: Synthetic amines are widely used in the polymer, dye, and pharmaceutical industries and produced millions of tons each year. Biogenic volatile amines are also widespread because amino-containing substances are ubiquitous natural constituents of all living beings. However, amines are usually toxic and corrosive to human skin, eyes, and respiratory system. Thus, the development of selective sensing materials for their detection has received considerable attentions in many fields, such as environmental and industrial monitoring, food quality control, and medical diagnoses. However, volatile amines are usually colorless and have no chromophoric or fluorophoric moiety, which makes their visual direct detection and discrimination difficult. For various approaches employed toward amine detection, for example, high-performance liquid chromatography, fluorometric analysis, gas chromatography coupled with mass spectrometry, and cyclic voltammetry, expensive instruments are necessary and not easily accessible on the spot in most cases. Chromic materials that change color upon contact with amines are desirable to develop more convenient and economical methods for rapid and visual on-site detection. Metal–organic coordination materials have proven to be intriguing platforms to design sensory systems for selective chemical detection. Most importantly, with variable compositions, structures, and functionalities, metal–organic materials possess strong advantages in that they can provide tunable analyte–receptor interactions to achieve target-specific chromic properties. Recent years have witnessed some work on the detection of amines using metal–organic materials. However, there are also some problems: (i) many detections are based on the coordination of amines to unsaturated metal ions, which usually make the materials unrecyclable owing to the structural collapse. (ii) It is difficult to design the sensing materials that can colorimetrically discriminate different amines because of similar mechanisms.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Synthetic amines are widely used in the polymer, dye, and pharmaceutical industries and produced millions of tons each year. Biogenic volatile amines are also widespread because amino-containing substances are ubiquitous natural constituents of all living beings. However, amines are usually toxic and corrosive to human skin, eyes, and respiratory system. Thus, the development of selective sensing materials for their detection has received considerable attentions in many fields, such as environmental and industrial monitoring, food quality control, and medical diagnoses. However, volatile amines are usually colorless and have no chromophoric or fluorophoric moiety, which makes their visual direct detection and discrimination difficult. For various approaches employed toward amine detection, for example, high-performance liquid chromatography, fluorometric analysis, gas chromatography coupled with mass spectrometry, and cyclic voltammetry, expensive instruments are necessary and not easily accessible on the spot in most cases. Chromic materials that change color upon contact with amines are desirable to develop more convenient and economical methods for rapid and visual on-site detection. Metal-organic coordination materials have proven to be intriguing platforms to design sensory systems for selective chemical detection. Most importantly, with variable compositions, structures, and functionalities, metal-organic materials possess strong advantages in that they can provide tunable analyte-receptor interactions to achieve target-specific chromic properties. Recent years have witnessed some work on the detection of amines using metal-organic materials. However, there are also some problems: (i) many detections are based on the coordination of amines to unsaturated metal ions, which usually make the materials unrecyclable owing to the structural collapse. (ii) It is difficult to design the sensing materials that can colorimetrically discriminate different amines because of similar mechanisms.

elements.content: Viologen derivatives (1,1′-disubstituted 4,4′-bipyridinium) have been well-known for electrochromism and photochromism. The electron-deficient viologen cation (V2+) is capable of forming the monocationic radical (V•+), with concomitant remarkable color change, through one-electron transfer from appropriate electron donors. Because amines are good electron donors, the introduction of viologen moiety into porous coordination materials can impart selectivity for visual sensing of amines, and moreover, appropriate pore size and surface properties could lead to discrimination between amines of different nature and sizes. Herein, along the line, we present a unique two-dimensional (2D) CdII coordination material (1) derived from 4,4′-bipyridinium-1,1′-bis­(phenylene-3-carboxylate) (m-bpybdc), which features viologen-lined one-dimensional (1D) channels. As expected, compound 1 shows reversible and differentiable color response to amines of different types (primary, secondary, and tertiary) and sizes, making it a potential candidate for practical detection. Additionally, the compound shows reversible photo- and hydrochromism. The chromic phenomena all involve stimuli-induced radical formation via reversible electron transfer. The compound can be easily deposited into paper, with which the differentiable visual detection of amines and erasable inkless printing are demonstrated.
elements.clean_text: Viologen derivatives (1,1'-disubstituted 4,4'-bipyridinium) have been well-known for electrochromism and photochromism. The electron-deficient viologen cation (V2+) is capable of forming the monocationic radical (V⋅+), with concomitant remarkable color change, through one-electron transfer from appropriate electron donors. Because amines are good electron donors, the introduction of viologen moiety into porous coordination materials can impart selectivity for visual sensing of amines, and moreover, appropriate pore size and surface properties could lead to discrimination between amines of different nature and sizes. Herein, along the line, we present a unique two-dimensional (2D) CdII coordination material (1) derived from 4,4'-bipyridinium-1,1'-bis(phenylene-3-carboxylate) (m-bpybdc), which features viologen-lined one-dimensional (1D) channels. As expected, compound 1 shows reversible and differentiable color response to amines of different types (primary, secondary, and tertiary) and sizes, making it a potential candidate for practical detection. Additionally, the compound shows reversible photo- and hydrochromism. The chromic phenomena all involve stimuli-induced radical formation via reversible electron transfer. The compound can be easily deposited into paper, with which the differentiable visual detection of amines and erasable inkless printing are demonstrated.

elements.content: [Cd2Cl­(m-bpybdc)2(H2O)4]­(NO3)3·7H2O (1) was prepared by mild reactions of Cd­(NO3)2·4H2O and [m-H2bpybdc]­Cl2 in water (for microcrystalline samples) or in mixed solvents (for single crystals). Single-crystal X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis revealed that 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic P21/c space group. As shown in a, each CdII ion is seven-coordinated in a distorted pentagonal bipyramidal geometry, with two bidentate chelating carboxyl groups and a chloride ion at the equatorial positions and with two water molecules as axial ligands. Two neighboring CdII ions are bridged into a dinuclear unit by a single chloride ion. The connection of the Cd2(μ-Cl) units by the m-bpybdc ligands leads to a 2D undulated coordination layer with the 44 topology (c). The ligand adopts a twisted conformation, for which the neighboring aromatic rings have dihedral angles of 41.4(1)–42.0(1)°, and the rings separated by a third ring are almost coplanar (dihedral angles < 1.3°). The undulation of the layer is defined by the obtuse angle (∼139°) between the coordination orientations of the two m-benzoate moieties (b). The 2D layers are packed with interdigitation between coordinated water molecules from different layers. The carboxylate groups from one layer form O–H···O and C–H···O hydrogen bonds with coordinated water molecules and pyridinium C–H groups from neighboring layers. There are also extensive interlayer π–π stacking interactions (d). Each pyridinium ring overlaps with a phenylene ring, and each phenylene ring overlaps with a pyridinium ring and another phenylene ring. The packing of layers leads to 1D quadrate channels (c) with dimensions 9.5 × 5.6 Å2 (measured by shortest H···H distances), which are occupied by nitrate ions and lattice water molecules.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Crystal Structure of 1 

[Cd2Cl(m-bpybdc)2(H2O)4](NO3)3⋅7H2O (1) was prepared by mild reactions of Cd(NO3)2⋅4H2O and [m-H2bpybdc]Cl2 in water (for microcrystalline samples) or in mixed solvents (for single crystals). Single-crystal X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis revealed that 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic P21/c space group. As shown in a, each CdII ion is seven-coordinated in a distorted pentagonal bipyramidal geometry, with two bidentate chelating carboxyl groups and a chloride ion at the equatorial positions and with two water molecules as axial ligands. Two neighboring CdII ions are bridged into a dinuclear unit by a single chloride ion. The connection of the Cd2(μ-Cl) units by the m-bpybdc ligands leads to a 2D undulated coordination layer with the 44 topology (c). The ligand adopts a twisted conformation, for which the neighboring aromatic rings have dihedral angles of 41.4(1)-42.0(1)°, and the rings separated by a third ring are almost coplanar (dihedral angles < 1.3°). The undulation of the layer is defined by the obtuse angle (~139°) between the coordination orientations of the two m-benzoate moieties (b). The 2D layers are packed with interdigitation between coordinated water molecules from different layers. The carboxylate groups from one layer form O-H⋅⋅⋅O and C-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonds with coordinated water molecules and pyridinium C-H groups from neighboring layers. There are also extensive interlayer π-π stacking interactions (d). Each pyridinium ring overlaps with a phenylene ring, and each phenylene ring overlaps with a pyridinium ring and another phenylene ring. The packing of layers leads to 1D quadrate channels (c) with dimensions 9.5 × 5.6 Å2 (measured by shortest H⋅⋅⋅H distances), which are occupied by nitrate ions and lattice water molecules.

elements.content: Structures of compound 1. (a) Coordination environment; (b) stacking of the undulated 2D layers; (c) 1D channels; and (d) interlayer π–π stacking interactions.
elements.clean_text: 1  Structures of compound 1. (a) Coordination environment; (b) stacking of the undulated 2D layers; (c) 1D channels; and (d) interlayer π-π stacking interactions.

elements.content: As found for many viologen-based derivatives, compound 1 is photochromic. It turns from yellow to dark green upon irradiation with a 300 W xenon lamp (b). Solid-state UV–vis and electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectroscopy were performed to confirm the involvement of radicals in this photochromic process. The UV–vis spectrum of the pristine state shows intense absorption below 400 nm with shoulders around 450 and 680 nm (a). The dark green state obtained after irradiation exhibits much more strong absorptions in the visible region, with maxima at 450, 670, and 724 nm. As shown in b, the dark green state presents a strong EPR signal with g = 2.0022, confirming the existence of photogenerated radicals. For comparison, a very weak signal at the same position appears in the EPR spectrum of the pristine yellow state. It was supposed that a small amount of free radicals was induced by the natural light. To confirm this, spectral measurements were performed with a sample kept in the dark for a long time. Indeed, the EPR signal and the shoulder visible-light absorption at 680 nm disappear (Figure S1). The absorption at 450 nm, which is responsible for the yellow color, remains for the sample kept in the dark, suggesting that the absorption is intrinsic to the nonradical state and could be because of charge–transfer transitions.
elements.clean_text:
Photochromism

As found for many viologen-based derivatives, compound 1 is photochromic. It turns from yellow to dark green upon irradiation with a 300 W xenon lamp (b). Solid-state UV-vis and electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectroscopy were performed to confirm the involvement of radicals in this photochromic process. The UV-vis spectrum of the pristine state shows intense absorption below 400 nm with shoulders around 450 and 680 nm (a). The dark green state obtained after irradiation exhibits much more strong absorptions in the visible region, with maxima at 450, 670, and 724 nm. As shown in b, the dark green state presents a strong EPR signal with g = 2.0022, confirming the existence of photogenerated radicals. For comparison, a very weak signal at the same position appears in the EPR spectrum of the pristine yellow state. It was supposed that a small amount of free radicals was induced by the natural light. To confirm this, spectral measurements were performed with a sample kept in the dark for a long time. Indeed, the EPR signal and the shoulder visible-light absorption at 680 nm disappear (Figure S1). The absorption at 450 nm, which is responsible for the yellow color, remains for the sample kept in the dark, suggesting that the absorption is intrinsic to the nonradical state and could be because of charge-transfer transitions.

elements.content: UV–vis spectra (a) and photographs and EPR spectra (b) of compound 1 before and after irradiation with a Xe lamp.
elements.clean_text: 2  UV-vis spectra (a) and photographs and EPR spectra (b) of compound 1 before and after irradiation with a Xe lamp.

elements.content: The powder XRD profiles and infrared (IR) spectra show no appreciable variations after photochromism (Figure S2), suggesting that the crystalline and molecular structures are maintained without bond cleavage or formation. To obtain the experimental evidence for the photoinduced electron transfer (PET) mechanism of radical formation, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was performed. Because of the inertness of CdII to PET, the Cd 3d core-level bands are almost the same before and after irradiation (). The N 1s bands are close to the Cd 3d5/2 peak. The band at 402.2 eV could be attributed to N in the pyridinium ring, whereas the signal of the nitrate N atom is submerged in the Cd 3d5/2 band. After irradiation, as shown in the enlarged part, an additional weak N 1s band appears at lower energy around 400.0 eV, indicating the formation of bipyridinium radicals. The O 1s spectrum of the pristine state appears as a broad envelope in the range from 529 to 535 eV. After irradiation, the band maximum is slightly lowered with a concomitant slight increase in relative intensity at the high-energy side, suggesting the loss of electron from some oxygen atoms. Lattice water, carboxylate, and nitrate all contribute to the observed O band. According to our previous work, water can be excluded from PET donors for its high ionization potential. Then, carboxylate and/or nitrate can be the possible electron donors for PET in 1. The Cl 2p3/2 and 2p1/2 peaks appear at 197.9 and 199.4 eV, respectively, before irradiation, and they shift to higher energy (198.1 and 199.7 eV, Figure S3) after irradiation. The shift confirms that the chloride ions are also electron donors for PET in 1.
elements.clean_text: The powder XRD profiles and infrared (IR) spectra show no appreciable variations after photochromism (Figure S2), suggesting that the crystalline and molecular structures are maintained without bond cleavage or formation. To obtain the experimental evidence for the photoinduced electron transfer (PET) mechanism of radical formation, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was performed. Because of the inertness of CdII to PET, the Cd 3d core-level bands are almost the same before and after irradiation (). The N 1s bands are close to the Cd 3d5/2 peak. The band at 402.2 eV could be attributed to N in the pyridinium ring, whereas the signal of the nitrate N atom is submerged in the Cd 3d5/2 band. After irradiation, as shown in the enlarged part, an additional weak N 1s band appears at lower energy around 400.0 eV, indicating the formation of bipyridinium radicals. The O 1s spectrum of the pristine state appears as a broad envelope in the range from 529 to 535 eV. After irradiation, the band maximum is slightly lowered with a concomitant slight increase in relative intensity at the high-energy side, suggesting the loss of electron from some oxygen atoms. Lattice water, carboxylate, and nitrate all contribute to the observed O band. According to our previous work, water can be excluded from PET donors for its high ionization potential. Then, carboxylate and/or nitrate can be the possible electron donors for PET in 1. The Cl 2p3/2 and 2p1/2 peaks appear at 197.9 and 199.4 eV, respectively, before irradiation, and they shift to higher energy (198.1 and 199.7 eV, Figure S3) after irradiation. The shift confirms that the chloride ions are also electron donors for PET in 1.

elements.content: XPS spectra of compound 1 before and after irradiation.
elements.clean_text: 3  XPS spectra of compound 1 before and after irradiation.

elements.content: In consistent with the XPS results, a closer inspection into the crystal structure gives evidence for the electron transfer from nitrate, carboxylate, and chloride to pyridinium. It has been recognized that weak intermolecular interactions between viologen and electron donors (D), such as NV···D, πV···n D, C–HV···D, or πV···π D, are necessary for PET. As shown in Figure S4, each nitrate in 1 forms five hydrogen bonds with C–H groups from viologen groups (H···O distances, 2.28–2.62 Å). For chloride ions, the shortest contacts with the viologen moiety are 3.39 and 3.59 Å (HV···Cl). For the carboxylate groups, there are two independent C–H···O hydrogen bonds with pyridinium rings (2.28 and 2.45 Å). The π–π stacking interactions between the pyridinium and benzene rings (3.59–3.70 Å. d) could also serve as electron-transfer pathways from carboxylate to viologen. Besides the intermolecular pathways, intramolecular electron transfer through the benzene ring between pyridinium and carboxylate cannot be excluded.
elements.clean_text: In consistent with the XPS results, a closer inspection into the crystal structure gives evidence for the electron transfer from nitrate, carboxylate, and chloride to pyridinium. It has been recognized that weak intermolecular interactions between viologen and electron donors (D), such as NV⋅⋅⋅D, πV⋅⋅⋅n D, C-HV⋅⋅⋅D, or πV⋅⋅⋅π D, are necessary for PET. As shown in Figure S4, each nitrate in 1 forms five hydrogen bonds with C-H groups from viologen groups (H⋅⋅⋅O distances, 2.28-2.62 Å). For chloride ions, the shortest contacts with the viologen moiety are 3.39 and 3.59 Å (HV⋅⋅⋅Cl). For the carboxylate groups, there are two independent C-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonds with pyridinium rings (2.28 and 2.45 Å). The π-π stacking interactions between the pyridinium and benzene rings (3.59-3.70 Å. d) could also serve as electron-transfer pathways from carboxylate to viologen. Besides the intermolecular pathways, intramolecular electron transfer through the benzene ring between pyridinium and carboxylate cannot be excluded.

elements.content: The photochromic process is reversible. The photogenerated green state bleaches back to the yellow state upon standing at ambient temperature for several minutes. The bleaching can occur either in air or nitrogen; therefore, the reverse mechanism is a spontaneous back-electron transfer rather than radical quenching by molecular oxygen. The photochromic and bleaching processes can be repeated without obvious fatigue (Figure S5).
elements.clean_text: The photochromic process is reversible. The photogenerated green state bleaches back to the yellow state upon standing at ambient temperature for several minutes. The bleaching can occur either in air or nitrogen; therefore, the reverse mechanism is a spontaneous back-electron transfer rather than radical quenching by molecular oxygen. The photochromic and bleaching processes can be repeated without obvious fatigue (Figure S5).

elements.content: Compound 1 also exhibits discernible hydrochromism in solid states. As shown in Figure S6, the as-synthesized yellow state turns dark green upon heating at 120 °C (Figure S6). Temperature-dependent in situ IR spectra and thermogravimetric analysis (Figures S7 and S8) indicate that 1 loses the lattice water and the coordinated water upon heating up to 120 °C (weight loss, 12.7%. Calcd 13.8%). With absorption maxima at 450, 670, and 724 nm, the UV–vis spectrum of the green state (Figure S6) is very similar to that of the photoinduced green state; therefore, the color change is also owing to radical formation through the electron transfer. The color change can also occur slowly by putting 1 at room temperature in a desiccator with concentrated sulfuric acid as the desiccant so that the chromic electron transfer was actually induced by dehydration rather than heat. The green state quickly returns to yellow upon contact with moist air for just several minutes. XRD results (Figure S9) indicate that the dehydrated green phase is amorphous and that the initial crystalline phase of 1 is recovered after exposing the amorphous phase to moisture. The recovery process occurs only in the presence of water, independent of the atmosphere (air, nitrogen, oxygen, or vacuum), suggesting that the radicals are not annihilated by molecular oxygen but by back-electron transfer concomitant with water-induced structural rearrangement. The reversible color switching by dehydration–hydration can be repeated (Figure S10). The anhydrous material can find applications in humidity sensing and monitoring. It is worth mentioning that the anhydrous state does not show color and structural changes upon contact with other common solvents such as methanol, acetonitrile, and N,N′-dimethyl formamide (either vapor or liquid); therefore, the hydrochromism is highly selective toward water (Figure S9).
elements.clean_text:
Hydrochromism

Compound 1 also exhibits discernible hydrochromism in solid states. As shown in Figure S6, the as-synthesized yellow state turns dark green upon heating at 120 °C (Figure S6). Temperature-dependent in situ IR spectra and thermogravimetric analysis (Figures S7 and S8) indicate that 1 loses the lattice water and the coordinated water upon heating up to 120 °C (weight loss, 12.7%. Calcd 13.8%). With absorption maxima at 450, 670, and 724 nm, the UV-vis spectrum of the green state (Figure S6) is very similar to that of the photoinduced green state; therefore, the color change is also owing to radical formation through the electron transfer. The color change can also occur slowly by putting 1 at room temperature in a desiccator with concentrated sulfuric acid as the desiccant so that the chromic electron transfer was actually induced by dehydration rather than heat. The green state quickly returns to yellow upon contact with moist air for just several minutes. XRD results (Figure S9) indicate that the dehydrated green phase is amorphous and that the initial crystalline phase of 1 is recovered after exposing the amorphous phase to moisture. The recovery process occurs only in the presence of water, independent of the atmosphere (air, nitrogen, oxygen, or vacuum), suggesting that the radicals are not annihilated by molecular oxygen but by back-electron transfer concomitant with water-induced structural rearrangement. The reversible color switching by dehydration-hydration can be repeated (Figure S10). The anhydrous material can find applications in humidity sensing and monitoring. It is worth mentioning that the anhydrous state does not show color and structural changes upon contact with other common solvents such as methanol, acetonitrile, and N,N'-dimethyl formamide (either vapor or liquid); therefore, the hydrochromism is highly selective toward water (Figure S9).

elements.content: The presence of the electron-deficient viologen moiety makes compound 1 capable to sense amines with high-contrast naked-eye color changes. The yellow compound shows different responses to different amines (). The compound becomes black immediately on exposure to the vapors of different primary amines, such as ethylamine, n-propylamine, n-butylamine, and cadaverine, but no appreciable color change occurs with t-butylamine. Fuming the compound with ammonia, dimethylamine, and diethylamine leads to different shades of green, but bulkier secondary amines (dipropylamine and diisopropylamine) cause no color change. In addition, the compound shows negative response to tertiary amines (triethylamine and triethylene diamine) and other common volatile organic compounds (VOCs) such as methanol, ethanol, acetonitrile, N,N′-dimethyl formamide, dichloromethane, chloroform, acetone, ethyl acetate, and nitrobenzene.
elements.clean_text:
Sensing of Amines Vapors

The presence of the electron-deficient viologen moiety makes compound 1 capable to sense amines with high-contrast naked-eye color changes. The yellow compound shows different responses to different amines (). The compound becomes black immediately on exposure to the vapors of different primary amines, such as ethylamine, n-propylamine, n-butylamine, and cadaverine, but no appreciable color change occurs with t-butylamine. Fuming the compound with ammonia, dimethylamine, and diethylamine leads to different shades of green, but bulkier secondary amines (dipropylamine and diisopropylamine) cause no color change. In addition, the compound shows negative response to tertiary amines (triethylamine and triethylene diamine) and other common volatile organic compounds (VOCs) such as methanol, ethanol, acetonitrile, N,N'-dimethyl formamide, dichloromethane, chloroform, acetone, ethyl acetate, and nitrobenzene.

elements.content: Photographs (a), UV–vis (b), and EPR (c) spectra of compound 1 before and after exposure to different amine vapors or solutions (in EtOH). EA = ethylamine, PA = n-propylamine, BA = n-butylamine, CA = cadaverine, tBA = t-butylamine, DMA = dimethylamine, DEA = diethylamine, DPA = dipropylamine, DiPA = diisopropylamine, TEA = triethylamine, and TEDA = triethylene diamine (0.1 M in EtOH).
elements.clean_text: 4  Photographs (a), UV-vis (b), and EPR (c) spectra of compound 1 before and after exposure to different amine vapors or solutions (in EtOH). EA = ethylamine, PA = n-propylamine, BA = n-butylamine, CA = cadaverine, tBA = t-butylamine, DMA = dimethylamine, DEA = diethylamine, DPA = dipropylamine, DiPA = diisopropylamine, TEA = triethylamine, and TEDA = triethylene diamine (0.1 M in EtOH).

elements.content: To verify the selective vapochromic mechanism, the solid-state UV–vis and EPR spectra of the samples fumed with different amines were measured. As shown in b, the UV–vis spectra of the black and dark green samples show almost full absorption in the visible region; the spectra of the green samples fumed with diethylamine and ammonia are similar to those of the dehydration- and photogenerated green states; and the amines giving negative color response cause no significant changes in the spectra. In addition, all of the black- and green-colored materials present strong single signals at g = 2.0023 in the EPR spectra (c). Therefore, considering the electron-rich character of the amine groups, the selective vapochromic phenomena can be because of generation of organic radicals through electron transfer from amines to the viologen moiety in 1.
elements.clean_text: To verify the selective vapochromic mechanism, the solid-state UV-vis and EPR spectra of the samples fumed with different amines were measured. As shown in b, the UV-vis spectra of the black and dark green samples show almost full absorption in the visible region; the spectra of the green samples fumed with diethylamine and ammonia are similar to those of the dehydration- and photogenerated green states; and the amines giving negative color response cause no significant changes in the spectra. In addition, all of the black- and green-colored materials present strong single signals at g = 2.0023 in the EPR spectra (c). Therefore, considering the electron-rich character of the amine groups, the selective vapochromic phenomena can be because of generation of organic radicals through electron transfer from amines to the viologen moiety in 1.

elements.content: There have been a few reports of viologen-based coordination polymers that show color response to ammonia or amines. However, the study of structure–property relationship is still lacking, and the differentiation between different amines has not been reported. As described above, compound 1 shows different color responses to primary and secondary amines with relatively small alkyl groups, whereas t-butylamine, dipropylamine, diisopropylamine, and tertiary amines give a negative response. It seems that the response can be correlated with the molecular size and especially the size of the groups around the N atom (the effective electron-donor atom interacting with the viologen moiety). The crystal structure of 1 was further examined for understanding the size effects. As described above, the 3D packing of the 2D coordination layers is sustained by interlayer hydrogen bonding and π–π stacking interactions, leading to relatively large channels. Closer inspection indicated that the nitrate ion in the channel interacts with two layers through a total of seven hydrogen bonds (O–H···O and C–H···O). It is reasonable to suppose that nitrate ions also play an important role in sustaining the 3D structure (). The amine molecule can potentially interact with the structure through hydrogen bonds (N–H···O, O–H···N, and C–H···N) and metal coordination, among which the C–H···N interaction with pyridinium can serve as a pathway for electron transfer. The N···pyridinium interaction from above the pyridinium ring is also often assigned as the electron-transfer pathway in viologen compounds, but the pathway is unlikely in 1 because of the face-to-face π–π stacking. The strongly hydrogen-bonded nitrate ions significantly reduce the dimensions of the channels to 5.2 × 5.6 Å2, and consequently the Cd coordination sphere (including water and carboxylate) is buried deep inside and not directly accessible to amines (). Therefore, the initial interaction sites should be the nitrate oxygen atoms and the aromatic C–H groups that are directly accessible to amines. Tertiary amines are relatively large and do not have N–H for strong interactions with nitrate. Furthermore, the C–H···N interactions with tertiary amines could be sterically restricted because of the relatively large hindrance between the three N-alkyl substituents and the surrounding of the C–H group. It could be for these reasons that 1 is silent to tertiary amines. For ammonia and relatively small primary/secondary amines, both N–H···O and C–H···N interactions could be operative for adsorption, and the interaction involving pyridinium leads to electron transfer and radical formation. Larger amines are disfavored because of size restriction on adsorption.
elements.clean_text: There have been a few reports of viologen-based coordination polymers that show color response to ammonia or amines. However, the study of structure-property relationship is still lacking, and the differentiation between different amines has not been reported. As described above, compound 1 shows different color responses to primary and secondary amines with relatively small alkyl groups, whereas t-butylamine, dipropylamine, diisopropylamine, and tertiary amines give a negative response. It seems that the response can be correlated with the molecular size and especially the size of the groups around the N atom (the effective electron-donor atom interacting with the viologen moiety). The crystal structure of 1 was further examined for understanding the size effects. As described above, the 3D packing of the 2D coordination layers is sustained by interlayer hydrogen bonding and π-π stacking interactions, leading to relatively large channels. Closer inspection indicated that the nitrate ion in the channel interacts with two layers through a total of seven hydrogen bonds (O-H⋅⋅⋅O and C-H⋅⋅⋅O). It is reasonable to suppose that nitrate ions also play an important role in sustaining the 3D structure (). The amine molecule can potentially interact with the structure through hydrogen bonds (N-H⋅⋅⋅O, O-H⋅⋅⋅N, and C-H⋅⋅⋅N) and metal coordination, among which the C-H⋅⋅⋅N interaction with pyridinium can serve as a pathway for electron transfer. The N⋅⋅⋅pyridinium interaction from above the pyridinium ring is also often assigned as the electron-transfer pathway in viologen compounds, but the pathway is unlikely in 1 because of the face-to-face π-π stacking. The strongly hydrogen-bonded nitrate ions significantly reduce the dimensions of the channels to 5.2 × 5.6 Å2, and consequently the Cd coordination sphere (including water and carboxylate) is buried deep inside and not directly accessible to amines (). Therefore, the initial interaction sites should be the nitrate oxygen atoms and the aromatic C-H groups that are directly accessible to amines. Tertiary amines are relatively large and do not have N-H for strong interactions with nitrate. Furthermore, the C-H⋅⋅⋅N interactions with tertiary amines could be sterically restricted because of the relatively large hindrance between the three N-alkyl substituents and the surrounding of the C-H group. It could be for these reasons that 1 is silent to tertiary amines. For ammonia and relatively small primary/secondary amines, both N-H⋅⋅⋅O and C-H⋅⋅⋅N interactions could be operative for adsorption, and the interaction involving pyridinium leads to electron transfer and radical formation. Larger amines are disfavored because of size restriction on adsorption.

elements.content: Multiple hydrogen-bonded nitrate ions that reduce the channel dimensions and help sustain the 3D structure.
elements.clean_text: 5  Multiple hydrogen-bonded nitrate ions that reduce the channel dimensions and help sustain the 3D structure.

elements.content: The IR spectra provide direct evidence for the adsorption. As can be seen in Figure S11, the spectra after fuming with ethylamine and diethylamine show new peaks at 2966, 2935, and 2875 cm–1, which are attributable to the alkyl νC–H absorption of the adsorbed amines. No obvious change was detected after fuming with t-butylamine and triethylamine, confirming the size effects on adsorption. XRD measurements provide further information on the chromic processes. As expected, the XRD profiles remain essentially unchanged for the samples fumed with unreactive amines. The reactive amines cause two different results. The black samples resulting from primary amines become amorphous, whereas the green samples from dimethylamine and diethylamine remain in the crystalline phase. The difference can be explained as follows. The primary NH2 group can form two N–H···O bonds with nitrate ions. The interactions are strong enough to destroy the hydrogen bonds between nitrates and two adjacent layers, which in turn leads to the collapse of the 3D packing. The structural collapse could lead to more favorable contacts between amine molecules and viologen moieties, and thereby more efficient electron transfer could occur to generate the black color. For secondary amines, it is likely that the N–H···O bond afforded by the NH group is not strong enough to destroy the structure; therefore, electron transfer occurs through the pathways limited by the crystalline structure.
elements.clean_text: The IR spectra provide direct evidence for the adsorption. As can be seen in Figure S11, the spectra after fuming with ethylamine and diethylamine show new peaks at 2966, 2935, and 2875 cm-1, which are attributable to the alkyl νC-H absorption of the adsorbed amines. No obvious change was detected after fuming with t-butylamine and triethylamine, confirming the size effects on adsorption. XRD measurements provide further information on the chromic processes. As expected, the XRD profiles remain essentially unchanged for the samples fumed with unreactive amines. The reactive amines cause two different results. The black samples resulting from primary amines become amorphous, whereas the green samples from dimethylamine and diethylamine remain in the crystalline phase. The difference can be explained as follows. The primary NH2 group can form two N-H⋅⋅⋅O bonds with nitrate ions. The interactions are strong enough to destroy the hydrogen bonds between nitrates and two adjacent layers, which in turn leads to the collapse of the 3D packing. The structural collapse could lead to more favorable contacts between amine molecules and viologen moieties, and thereby more efficient electron transfer could occur to generate the black color. For secondary amines, it is likely that the N-H⋅⋅⋅O bond afforded by the NH group is not strong enough to destroy the structure; therefore, electron transfer occurs through the pathways limited by the crystalline structure.

elements.content: The deep-colored samples after amine exposure can be recovered to the pristine state. The ammonia-fumed green sample readily turns yellow after standing in air for 2 min. For samples colored by organic amines, standing at room temperature in air only leads to lighter shades, but color recovery can be achieved by heating the samples in air at 80 °C. The coloration–decoloration process has been repeated for five cycles, during which the phase change is monitored by XRD. As shown in Figure S12, the crystalline integrity of 1 is maintained during the cycles with diethylamine, whereas coloration with ethylamine leads to an amorphous phase, which regains crystallinity after heating and subsequent exposure to moist air. In the latter case, it is found that the exposure to moisture after heat-assisted color recovery is necessary for the structural recovery, suggesting that the reconstruction of the crystalline structure is induced by water adsorption.
elements.clean_text: The deep-colored samples after amine exposure can be recovered to the pristine state. The ammonia-fumed green sample readily turns yellow after standing in air for 2 min. For samples colored by organic amines, standing at room temperature in air only leads to lighter shades, but color recovery can be achieved by heating the samples in air at 80 °C. The coloration-decoloration process has been repeated for five cycles, during which the phase change is monitored by XRD. As shown in Figure S12, the crystalline integrity of 1 is maintained during the cycles with diethylamine, whereas coloration with ethylamine leads to an amorphous phase, which regains crystallinity after heating and subsequent exposure to moist air. In the latter case, it is found that the exposure to moisture after heat-assisted color recovery is necessary for the structural recovery, suggesting that the reconstruction of the crystalline structure is induced by water adsorption.

elements.content: The chromic properties of 1 have implications for applications in display and sensing. Two methods (a) have been tried for the fabrication of 1-loaded paper (denoted as 1-paper). Considering that compound 1 can be recrystallized by evaporating its aqueous solution to dry (Figure S13), 1-paper can be easily prepared by spraying an aqueous solution of 1 onto the filter paper. Alternatively and more simply, an aqueous solution containing the organic ligand and cadmium nitrate can be directly used for the preparation of 1-paper, for which the step for advanced synthesis of 1 was skipped. Both methods lead to light-colored paper. XRD confirms that the crystalline phase of 1 is loaded onto the paper (Figure S14). The scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images suggest that 1 crystallizes as microcrystals wrapped within the paper (c).
elements.clean_text:
Test Paper Applications

The chromic properties of 1 have implications for applications in display and sensing. Two methods (a) have been tried for the fabrication of 1-loaded paper (denoted as 1-paper). Considering that compound 1 can be recrystallized by evaporating its aqueous solution to dry (Figure S13), 1-paper can be easily prepared by spraying an aqueous solution of 1 onto the filter paper. Alternatively and more simply, an aqueous solution containing the organic ligand and cadmium nitrate can be directly used for the preparation of 1-paper, for which the step for advanced synthesis of 1 was skipped. Both methods lead to light-colored paper. XRD confirms that the crystalline phase of 1 is loaded onto the paper (Figure S14). The scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images suggest that 1 crystallizes as microcrystals wrapped within the paper (c).

elements.content: Schematic representation of the preparation of 1-paper (a), SEM images of the blank filter paper (b) and 1-paper (c), and photographs of 1-paper stenciled with a lotus motif by photoirradiation (d).
elements.clean_text: 6  Schematic representation of the preparation of 1-paper (a), SEM images of the blank filter paper (b) and 1-paper (c), and photographs of 1-paper stenciled with a lotus motif by photoirradiation (d).

elements.content: Similar to the powder sample of 1, 1-paper is photochromic, which implies the application as inkless and erasable printing media. As shown in d, after irradiating a piece of 1-paper covered with a stencil, the lotus pattern was printed in green with high contrast for visual reading. The pattern disappeared after standing in air for 15 min, and the paper could be reused for the next round of light printing. The color of the lotus pattern remains comparable in the repeating cycles.
elements.clean_text: Similar to the powder sample of 1, 1-paper is photochromic, which implies the application as inkless and erasable printing media. As shown in d, after irradiating a piece of 1-paper covered with a stencil, the lotus pattern was printed in green with high contrast for visual reading. The pattern disappeared after standing in air for 15 min, and the paper could be reused for the next round of light printing. The color of the lotus pattern remains comparable in the repeating cycles.

elements.content: Chemically specific colorimetric test papers are the simplest and most convenient devices for qualitative chemical sensing. Light-colored 1-paper turns to bright yellow when exposed to sterically unhindered primary amines, whereas ammonia, dimethylamine, and diethylamine lead to different green colors (). Electron spin resonance confirmed that the vapochromic response of 1-paper is associated with radical formation (Figure S15), as demonstrated above for the bulk sample. The paper is silent to tertiary, bulky primary/secondary amines, and other common VOCs. The results suggest that 1-paper and the bulk sample of 1 show similar selective and discriminative abilities toward amines, although they show different color responses (yellow vs black) to primary amines. The paper fumed with the primary amines remains yellow when kept at room temperature and changes to a deeper color when heated; the resulting paper is no longer responsive to amines. These suggest that the primary amines lead to irreversible permanent structural changes and 1-paper acts as a one-time disposable test paper for low-carbon primary amines. The different behaviors between 1-paper and the bulk sample suggest that the analyte–receptor interactions and structural reconstruction should be affected by the paper support through some unclear mechanism. However, 1-paper and the bulk sample are very similar in their response to secondary amines: they show similar green colors and the chromic processes are reversible. The observations are understandable because secondary amines do not destroy the crystalline structure of 1 (see above), which could imply that the chromic process is not easily influenced by external factors such as the paper support. The amine-fumed green paper can bleach to the original color after standing in air at room temperature for 15 min. Five cycles of coloration–decoloration have been successfully performed with diethylamine. The results suggest that 1-paper can be used as a portable test paper for quick, naked-eye, and differentiable detection of low-carbon amines. The test paper is one-time for primary amines but reusable for secondary ones.
elements.clean_text: Chemically specific colorimetric test papers are the simplest and most convenient devices for qualitative chemical sensing. Light-colored 1-paper turns to bright yellow when exposed to sterically unhindered primary amines, whereas ammonia, dimethylamine, and diethylamine lead to different green colors (). Electron spin resonance confirmed that the vapochromic response of 1-paper is associated with radical formation (Figure S15), as demonstrated above for the bulk sample. The paper is silent to tertiary, bulky primary/secondary amines, and other common VOCs. The results suggest that 1-paper and the bulk sample of 1 show similar selective and discriminative abilities toward amines, although they show different color responses (yellow vs black) to primary amines. The paper fumed with the primary amines remains yellow when kept at room temperature and changes to a deeper color when heated; the resulting paper is no longer responsive to amines. These suggest that the primary amines lead to irreversible permanent structural changes and 1-paper acts as a one-time disposable test paper for low-carbon primary amines. The different behaviors between 1-paper and the bulk sample suggest that the analyte-receptor interactions and structural reconstruction should be affected by the paper support through some unclear mechanism. However, 1-paper and the bulk sample are very similar in their response to secondary amines: they show similar green colors and the chromic processes are reversible. The observations are understandable because secondary amines do not destroy the crystalline structure of 1 (see above), which could imply that the chromic process is not easily influenced by external factors such as the paper support. The amine-fumed green paper can bleach to the original color after standing in air at room temperature for 15 min. Five cycles of coloration-decoloration have been successfully performed with diethylamine. The results suggest that 1-paper can be used as a portable test paper for quick, naked-eye, and differentiable detection of low-carbon amines. The test paper is one-time for primary amines but reusable for secondary ones.

elements.content: Photographs of 1-paper before and after fuming with different amines.
elements.clean_text: 7  Photographs of 1-paper before and after fuming with different amines.

elements.content: In conclusion, we have prepared a metal–organic coordination polymer with 1D channels lined with electron-deficient viologen. Owing to stimuli-induced radical formation through the electron-transfer mechanism, the compound is photochromic and hydrochromic and shows very sensitive and reversible naked-eye differentiable vapochromic response to different amines. The selective and discriminative vapochromism toward amines is because (1) the amine group is a good electron donor, (2) different types (primary, secondary, and tertiary) of amines show different hydrogen bonding interactions with the accessible sites in the channel, (3) the interactions are affected by geometrical factors such as the size of the analyte molecule relative to the receptor channel and the steric hindrance for amine N to approach the viologen moiety, and (4) the interactions of different strengths can or cannot cause structural transformation, which in turn has impacts on the analyte–receptor interactions and electron transfer. To the best of our knowledge, this work is the first to colorimetrically differentiate primary, secondary, and tertiary low-carbon amines. It is noteworthy that the complex can be easily deposited onto paper for portable differentiable detection of amines and erasable inkless printing.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In conclusion, we have prepared a metal-organic coordination polymer with 1D channels lined with electron-deficient viologen. Owing to stimuli-induced radical formation through the electron-transfer mechanism, the compound is photochromic and hydrochromic and shows very sensitive and reversible naked-eye differentiable vapochromic response to different amines. The selective and discriminative vapochromism toward amines is because (1) the amine group is a good electron donor, (2) different types (primary, secondary, and tertiary) of amines show different hydrogen bonding interactions with the accessible sites in the channel, (3) the interactions are affected by geometrical factors such as the size of the analyte molecule relative to the receptor channel and the steric hindrance for amine N to approach the viologen moiety, and (4) the interactions of different strengths can or cannot cause structural transformation, which in turn has impacts on the analyte-receptor interactions and electron transfer. To the best of our knowledge, this work is the first to colorimetrically differentiate primary, secondary, and tertiary low-carbon amines. It is noteworthy that the complex can be easily deposited onto paper for portable differentiable detection of amines and erasable inkless printing.

elements.content: A mixture of [m-H2bpybdc]­Cl2 (0.05 mmol, 0.024 g), Cd­(NO3)2·4H2O (0.60 mmol, 0.188 g), H2O (2 mL), EtOH (2 mL), MeCN (2 mL), DMF (2 mL), and MeOH (2 mL) was stirred for 15 min, then sealed in a 20 mL vial, and kept at 80 °C for 12 h. Crystals of 1 were obtained after slowly cooling the mixture to room temperature (48% yield based on ligand). Polycrystalline powder of the compound can be prepared in larger scale by a simple mixing-and-evaporation procedure: a solution of [m-H2bpybdc]­Cl2 (0.02 mmol, 10 mg) in 1.5 mL water was neutralized to pH ≈ 7 using an aqueous NaOH solution (0.1 mol·L–1). Cd­(NO3)2 (0.025 mmol, 7.6 mg) dissolved in a small amount of water (0.125 mL) was added to the above solution. After filtering off the tiny precipitates, evaporation of the yellow solution at room temperature afforded the microcrystalline solid. The XRD profiles of the microcrystalline and single-crystal samples are consistent (Figure S13). Elemental Anal. Calcd for C48H54Cd2ClN7O28 (M = 1437.25): C, 40.11; H, 3.79; N, 6.82. Found: C, 39.72; H, 4.01; N, 6.53%.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Synthesis of 1 

A mixture of [m-H2bpybdc]Cl2 (0.05 mmol, 0.024 g), Cd(NO3)2⋅4H2O (0.60 mmol, 0.188 g), H2O (2 mL), EtOH (2 mL), MeCN (2 mL), DMF (2 mL), and MeOH (2 mL) was stirred for 15 min, then sealed in a 20 mL vial, and kept at 80 °C for 12 h. Crystals of 1 were obtained after slowly cooling the mixture to room temperature (48% yield based on ligand). Polycrystalline powder of the compound can be prepared in larger scale by a simple mixing-and-evaporation procedure: a solution of [m-H2bpybdc]Cl2 (0.02 mmol, 10 mg) in 1.5 mL water was neutralized to pH ~ 7 using an aqueous NaOH solution (0.1 mol⋅L-1). Cd(NO3)2 (0.025 mmol, 7.6 mg) dissolved in a small amount of water (0.125 mL) was added to the above solution. After filtering off the tiny precipitates, evaporation of the yellow solution at room temperature afforded the microcrystalline solid. The XRD profiles of the microcrystalline and single-crystal samples are consistent (Figure S13). Elemental Anal. Calcd for C48H54Cd2ClN7O28 (M = 1437.25): C, 40.11; H, 3.79; N, 6.82. Found: C, 39.72; H, 4.01; N, 6.53%.

elements.content: C48H54Cd2ClN7O28: M r = 1437.23, space group P21/c, a = 9.7499(2), b = 18.3486(4), c = 16.6672(4), β = 101.3530(10)°, T = 173(2) K, Z = 2, V = 2923.37(11) Å3, D c = 1.633 g cm–3, μ = 7.068 mm–1, F(000) = 1456 and GOF = 1.007. 26 884 reflections collected, 5312 unique (R int = 0.0583). R 1 = 0.0454, wR 2 = 0.1180 [I > 2σ­(I)]. CCDC 1818436 contains the supplementary crystallographic data for this paper. These data are provided free of charge by The Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre.
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Data for 1 

C48H54Cd2ClN7O28: M r = 1437.23, space group P21/c, a = 9.7499(2), b = 18.3486(4), c = 16.6672(4), β = 101.3530(10)°, T = 173(2) K, Z = 2, V = 2923.37(11) Å3, D c = 1.633 g cm-3, μ = 7.068 mm-1, F(000) = 1456 and GOF = 1.007. 26884 reflections collected, 5312 unique (R int = 0.0583). R 1 = 0.0454, wR 2 = 0.1180 [I > 2σ(I)]. CCDC 1818436 contains the supplementary crystallographic data for this paper. These data are provided free of charge by The Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre.

elements.content: A stock solution was prepared by dissolving 1 (30 mg, 0.02 mmol) in water (5 mL). The solution (3.5 mL) was sprayed onto a piece of cellulose filter paper (4 × 2.5 cm2) using a spray bottle, and the paper was dried in air at room temperature. The spraying-drying procedure was repeated 5 times. Alternatively, the stock solution was prepared by dissolving Cd­(NO3)2 (13 mg, 0.04 mmol) and [m-H2bpybdc]­Cl2 (20 mg, 0.04 mmol) in water (5 mL), and the solution was neutralized to pH ≈ 7 using an aqueous NaOH solution (0.1 M). The paper prepared by the two methods shows identical chromic behaviors, but the XRD profiles are the same as that for the bare paper. The XRD peaks of 1 are evident for the paper prepared by repeating the spraying-drying procedure 20 times (Figure S14).
elements.clean_text:
Preparation of 1-Paper 

A stock solution was prepared by dissolving 1 (30 mg, 0.02 mmol) in water (5 mL). The solution (3.5 mL) was sprayed onto a piece of cellulose filter paper (4 × 2.5 cm2) using a spray bottle, and the paper was dried in air at room temperature. The spraying-drying procedure was repeated 5 times. Alternatively, the stock solution was prepared by dissolving Cd(NO3)2 (13 mg, 0.04 mmol) and [m-H2bpybdc]Cl2 (20 mg, 0.04 mmol) in water (5 mL), and the solution was neutralized to pH ~ 7 using an aqueous NaOH solution (0.1 M). The paper prepared by the two methods shows identical chromic behaviors, but the XRD profiles are the same as that for the bare paper. The XRD peaks of 1 are evident for the paper prepared by repeating the spraying-drying procedure 20 times (Figure S14).

elements.content: The content printing on 1-paper was performed by controlling the incidence of the light through a stencil. The printing surface of 1-paper was covered with the stencil and irradiated by a Xe lamp (300 W, 20 cm) for 2 min. After removing the stencil, the content was printed clearly in green.
elements.clean_text:
Procedure of Content Printing

The content printing on 1-paper was performed by controlling the incidence of the light through a stencil. The printing surface of 1-paper was covered with the stencil and irradiated by a Xe lamp (300 W, 20 cm) for 2 min. After removing the stencil, the content was printed clearly in green.

cln_elements.content:
Compound 1 also exhibits discernible hydrochromism in solid states. As shown in Figure S6, the as-synthesized yellow state turns dark green upon heating at 120 °C (Figure S6). Temperature-dependent in situ IR spectra and thermogravimetric analysis (Figures S7 and S8) indicate that 1 loses the lattice water and the coordinated water upon heating up to 120 °C (weight loss, 12.7%. Calcd 13.8%). With absorption maxima at 450, 670, and 724 nm, the UV–vis spectrum of the green state (Figure S6) is very similar to that of the photoinduced green state; therefore, the color change is also owing to radical formation through the electron transfer. The color change can also occur slowly by putting 1 at room temperature in a desiccator with concentrated sulfuric acid as the desiccant so that the chromic electron transfer was actually induced by dehydration rather than heat. The green state quickly returns to yellow upon contact with moist air for just several minutes. XRD results (Figure S9) indicate that the dehydrated green phase is amorphous and that the initial crystalline phase of 1 is recovered after exposing the amorphous phase to moisture. The recovery process occurs only in the presence of water, independent of the atmosphere (air, nitrogen, oxygen, or vacuum), suggesting that the radicals are not annihilated by molecular oxygen but by back-electron transfer concomitant with water-induced structural rearrangement. The reversible color switching by dehydration–hydration can be repeated (Figure S10). The anhydrous material can find applications in humidity sensing and monitoring. It is worth mentioning that the anhydrous state does not show color and structural changes upon contact with other common solvents such as methanol, acetonitrile, and N,N′-dimethyl formamide (either vapor or liquid); therefore, the hydrochromism is highly selective toward water (Figure S9).

Crystal Data for <bold>1</bold>

C48H54Cd2ClN7O28: M r = 1437.23, space group P21/c, a = 9.7499(2), b = 18.3486(4), c = 16.6672(4), β = 101.3530(10)°, T = 173(2) K, Z = 2, V = 2923.37(11) Å3, D c = 1.633 g cm–3, μ = 7.068 mm–1, F(000) = 1456 and GOF = 1.007. 26 884 reflections collected, 5312 unique (R int = 0.0583). R 1 = 0.0454, wR 2 = 0.1180 [I > 2σ­(I)]. CCDC 1818436 contains the supplementary crystallographic data for this paper. These data are provided free of charge by The Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Hydrochromism

Compound 1 also exhibits discernible hydrochromism in solid states. As shown in Figure S6, the as-synthesized yellow state turns dark green upon heating at 120 °C (Figure S6). Temperature-dependent in situ IR spectra and thermogravimetric analysis (Figures S7 and S8) indicate that 1 loses the lattice water and the coordinated water upon heating up to 120 °C (weight loss, 12.7%. Calcd 13.8%). With absorption maxima at 450, 670, and 724 nm, the UV-vis spectrum of the green state (Figure S6) is very similar to that of the photoinduced green state; therefore, the color change is also owing to radical formation through the electron transfer. The color change can also occur slowly by putting 1 at room temperature in a desiccator with concentrated sulfuric acid as the desiccant so that the chromic electron transfer was actually induced by dehydration rather than heat. The green state quickly returns to yellow upon contact with moist air for just several minutes. XRD results (Figure S9) indicate that the dehydrated green phase is amorphous and that the initial crystalline phase of 1 is recovered after exposing the amorphous phase to moisture. The recovery process occurs only in the presence of water, independent of the atmosphere (air, nitrogen, oxygen, or vacuum), suggesting that the radicals are not annihilated by molecular oxygen but by back-electron transfer concomitant with water-induced structural rearrangement. The reversible color switching by dehydration-hydration can be repeated (Figure S10). The anhydrous material can find applications in humidity sensing and monitoring. It is worth mentioning that the anhydrous state does not show color and structural changes upon contact with other common solvents such as methanol, acetonitrile, and N,N'-dimethyl formamide (either vapor or liquid); therefore, the hydrochromism is highly selective toward water (Figure S9).

Crystal Data for 1 

C48H54Cd2ClN7O28: M r = 1437.23, space group P21/c, a = 9.7499(2), b = 18.3486(4), c = 16.6672(4), β = 101.3530(10)°, T = 173(2) K, Z = 2, V = 2923.37(11) Å3, D c = 1.633 g cm-3, μ = 7.068 mm-1, F(000) = 1456 and GOF = 1.007. 26884 reflections collected, 5312 unique (R int = 0.0583). R 1 = 0.0454, wR 2 = 0.1180 [I > 2σ(I)]. CCDC 1818436 contains the supplementary crystallographic data for this paper. These data are provided free of charge by The Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre.

cln_elements.content: Structures of compound 1. (a) Coordination environment; (b) stacking of the undulated 2D layers; (c) 1D channels; and (d) interlayer π–π stacking interactions.

cln_elements.content: Photographs (a), UV–vis (b), and EPR (c) spectra of compound 1 before and after exposure to different amine vapors or solutions (in EtOH). EA = ethylamine, PA = n-propylamine, BA = n-butylamine, CA = cadaverine, tBA = t-butylamine, DMA = dimethylamine, DEA = diethylamine, DPA = dipropylamine, DiPA = diisopropylamine, TEA = triethylamine, and TEDA = triethylene diamine (0.1 M in EtOH).
cln_elements.clean_text: 4  Photographs (a), UV-vis (b), and EPR (c) spectra of compound 1 before and after exposure to different amine vapors or solutions (in EtOH). EA = ethylamine, PA = n-propylamine, BA = n-butylamine, CA = cadaverine, tBA = t-butylamine, DMA = dimethylamine, DEA = diethylamine, DPA = dipropylamine, DiPA = diisopropylamine, TEA = triethylamine, and TEDA = triethylene diamine (0.1 M in EtOH).

cln_elements.content: Multiple hydrogen-bonded nitrate ions that reduce the channel dimensions and help sustain the 3D structure.
